sglaine
Ford all the way Baby!!!!!!!!!!! emoticon_xhoho emoticon_xagree emoticon_xgood emoticon_xagree Ford F-250 and F-350 RULES
Big Orn

There has never really been a small truck that has ever worked harder and lasted longer than Ford IMHO. Sure, they rider rougher, but what's a truck for, anyway?
 
 V10 vs Diesel? I prefer the V10 due to its pulling power without the heavy toll on the front. The new Ford 6.0 is something I haven't had much dealings with, but could be the engine of the future for me. I use 4x4 almost all the time in one way or the other; if it's not the 4 wheels pulling, it's the lower gearing from the transfer case.
 
 I have yet to see the benefits of synthetic oil...except in gearing/hydraulics.
 
 Fabtech is a popular lift kit, but it's really just another version of the others.
 I have never bought a lift kit, just built my own for each vehicle. I have even found that coil-over-leaf is a good route if you add the rails to prevent axle wrap. (Of course coil-over-leaf is bad in the front and drop-shackles or re-arched springs might be better.) For the front I have even removed leaf springs from the rear of donor trucks and installed them on the front. Not much difference if you do a little searching.
 
 BTW - Haulingboat, I have noticed that you are an unknown quatity at this point. Whose chain did you pull this time?

Haulingboat

I experienced the value of sythetic oil at a motorcycle rally in Austin. We were stuck in traffic in 100 degree weather on air cooled bikes. To say the least they got a little warm. I was pleased to know that I had oil in the bike that would not break down. Since then we have been running it in all our vehicles.
Big Orn

I experienced the value of sythetic oil at a motorcycle rally in Austin. We were stuck in traffic in 100 degree weather on air cooled bikes. To say the least they got a little warm. I was pleased to know that I had oil in the bike that would not break down. Since then we have been running it in all our vehicles.

 I can see your point, Haulingboat, but I was referring to truck engines. I agree that in extreme circumstances synthetic wins hands-down.
 
 In truck engines, where extremes are few and far between, I have used dino and syn, and have not found any significant benefits in the syns. I suppose the engines still get nasty, just not as bad as they once did.
Haulingboat

I can see your point, Haulingboat, but I was referring to truck engines. I agree that in extreme circumstances synthetic wins hands-down.
 
 In truck engines, where extremes are few and far between, I have used dino and syn, and have not found any significant benefits in the syns. I suppose the engines still get nasty, just not as bad as they once did.

 
 It is also piece of mind when I or my wife go a little beyond the recommended oil change intervals. If my wife overheats and doesn't notice the gauge before she has reached the extreme at least I know her oil is not going to break down. 
 
 For me, it is worth the extra money. There is no telling when those episodes are going to sneak up on you. I feel better equipt to withstand those situations knowing sythetic is in the motor.
Big Orn

If my wife overheats...

whistler

Hey Whistler check out this site www.pistonslap.com

 
 I've been to this site and poked around. Luckily after 15,000 miles the truck doesn't have this problem. Neither does my wife's Malibu @ 60,000. 
 
 It's hard to say whether I would have bought the truck if I had known about GM's attitude towards this problem. IMHO, all vehicle makes have their bugs with certain componants, that doesn't really play into my considerations for vehicles. What is truly galling is how GM has decided to handle piston slap by calling it normal and refusing to help out customers. Had I realized what was happening I would have thought long and hard about the truck.
 
 Whistler
